docs.lead_paragraph: The number of businesses in New Jersey offering managed care insurance plans to their employees has doubled over the last four years, according to a survey released yesterday. The survey, conducted by the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, found that more than 80 percent of their 15,000 affiliated businesses offered managed care plans to employees in 1997, compared with just 42 percent in 1993. On average, managed care plans cost just over $4,000 per employee last year, about $800 less than the average indemnity plan, according to the survey.

headline.main: Managed Care Is Found To Grow in Popularity

docs.abstract: NJ Business and Industry Assn survey finds that number of businesses in New Jersey offering managed care insurance plans to their employees has doubled over last four years (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: MOST New Yorkers would be unable to distinguish James F. Gill from the countless other men of pomegranate complexion and profane good cheer celebrating themselves in today's St. Patrick's Day parade. But the state's most powerful politicians know exactly who he is. For several years now, Mr. Gill has been the official supplier of Irish wit and political advice to men like Gov. George E. Pataki, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and former Mayor Edward I. Koch, filling in the enormous Gaelic gaps in their souls. When either the Governor or the Senator needs to speak to a group like the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, they turn to Mr. Gill, who writes them remarks groaning with Irish humor, which they deliver word for word to uproarious laughter.

headline.main: A Power Broker With Blarney in His Pen

docs.abstract: James F Gill, managing partner of Robinson Silverman Pearce Aronsohn & Berman law firm, is 'official' supplier of Irish wit and political advice to Gov George E Pataki and other New York politicians on St Patrick's Day; Gill photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A 1996 law hailed as a way to guarantee health insurance for millions of Americans when they change jobs or lose coverage is not working as Congress intended, Federal investigators say. The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, found that people who exercised their rights under the law were often charged premiums far higher than the standard rates. And it said that some companies discouraged insurance agents from selling policies to people with medical problems, the very people who were supposed to benefit from the law.

headline.main: HIGH RATES HOBBLE LAW TO GUARANTEE HEALTH INSURANCE

docs.abstract: Federal investigators say law passed by Congress in 1996 and hailed as way to guarantee health insurance for millions of Americans when they change jobs or lose coverage is not working as intended; General Accounting Office says people who exercised rights under law are often charged premiums far higher than standard rates; some insurance companies reportedly discourage agents from selling policies to people with medical problems, who were especially supposed to benefit from law; Sen Edward Kennedy, co-author of legislation, says further Federal action may be needed to limit excessive premium increases for such individuals, but Republicans are likely to oppose Federal regulation of insurance rates, as they did in 1996 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Benjamin Spock, the pediatrician who gently coached anxious postwar parents to trust their ''own common sense,'' only to be blamed by some critics for the self-indulgence of those parents' children, the 60's generation, died on Sunday at his home in San Diego. He was 94. Over half a century, Dr. Spock's homey handbook on child care, now titled ''Dr. Spock's Baby and Child Care,'' became one of the best sellers of all time. Therese Zazycki, a spokeswoman for Pocket Books, its main publisher, said yesterday that almost 50 million copies have been sold around the world, translated into 42 languages.

headline.main: Benjamin Spock, World's Pediatrician, Dies at 94

docs.abstract: Dr Benjamin Spock, noted pediatrician who gently coached anxious postwar parents to trust common sense in caring for children but was blamed by critics for self-indulgence of 60's generation, dies at age 94; his homey handbook, Dr Spock's Baby and Child Care, was one of bestsellers of all time for more than 50 years; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A COMMON response of people who learn that a woman is being battered by the man she lives with is: ''Why doesn't she leave? What kind of woman is she to stay with a man who beats her?'' But experts on domestic violence and the women who are its victims say these questions, though well-meaning, reflect profound ignorance of the tenacious hold abusive men can have on their partners and the often-limited options available to women in abusive relationships. Such a woman faces two major obstacles: fear and finances -- fear for her safety and that of her children and a lack of money to support herself or them. The most dangerous time in the life of a battered woman is when she attempts to leave her abuser. Threatened by the loss of control, the batterer is likely to become even more violent and may even try to kill her. There are simply not enough shelters to protect all the women who need them.

headline.main: Planning to Escape From an Abusive Relationship

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column offers guidance to women planning to escape from an abusive relationship; holds primary tasks of a woman trapped in a violent relationship are to learn about resources in her community that can help her and to develop plan that can protect her and her children while she is still in relationship and when she is ready to get out (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dow Surges 116 Points, As Market Sets Records Stock market indexes soared to records, as investors bought on expectations of strong corporate profits and declining interest rates -- the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.86 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average surged 116.33 points, or 1.35 percent, to 8,718.85, closing above 8,700 for the first time. Since the beginning of the year, the Dow has risen 810.60 points, or 10.25 percent. [Page D10.]

docs.lead_paragraph: In the psychology of the stock market, buying begets buying. Major stock market indexes soared to records yesterday, as investors, seeing a rosy economic outlook of declining interest rates and strong corporate profits, rushed to buy stocks.

headline.main: Buoyant Investors Push Dow Above 8,700 for First Time

docs.abstract: Major stock market indexes soar to records as investors rush to buy stocks, encouraged by rosy economic outlook of declining interest rates and strong corporate profits, as well as assuring remarks by Warren Buffett, famed value investor; Dow Jones industrial average surges 116.33 points to 8,718.85, closing above 8,700 for first time; Standard & Poor's 500 index gains 1 percent, or 10.66 points, to close at 1,079.27, another record; graphs (M)
docs.snippet: In the psychology of the stock market, buying begets buying.     Major stock market indexes soared to records yesterday, as investors, seeing a rosy economic outlook of declining interest rates and strong corporate profits, rushed to buy stocks.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Hindu Nationalists to Rule, But Face Policy Limits Atal Bihari Vajpayee, the parliamentary leader of India's main Hindu nationalist party, was summoned to the presidential palace and handed a letter asking him to become Prime Minister. The invitation to establish a Government ended the party's wait for power, but the circumstances appeared to leave little room for the Hindu supremacist policies that are anathema to the country's 120 million Muslims. A1 China To Gain New Premier Zhu Rongji, who is expected to be named Prime Minister of China on Tuesday, is a career Communist planner who has won the respect of other Chinese leaders and Western business executives. He will become head of China's Cabinet at a time when the world's most populous country is emerging as an economic and political heavyweight. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: A Mall for the Meadowlands A developer plans to build a huge shopping mall in New Jersey's Meadowlands, but environmentalists are utterly opposed to the loss of 206 acres of wetlands.
